EXECUTIVE SUMMARY||RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



A.   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Zenith Logistics, Inc. Kentucky Distribution Center recognizes management's responsibility in protecting its employees, the public, the environment, equipment, and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are of primary importance.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the Louisville facility.

To accomplish the company's goal in preventing accidents, the facility has established a Plant Safety Program.  The objectives of the Plant Safety Program are to: maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.

One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).  The Maintenance Manager is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.

The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs help prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses environmental impacts and physical property damage.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, and/or equipment.  These rules are detailed and

improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.

In addition to the Plant Safety Program, Kentucky Distribution Center follows these corporate safety guidelines. 



     Employee Handbook Plant Safety Rules

     Zenith Logistics Contractor Safety Rules

     Zenith Safety Inspection and Abatement Plans

     Safety Process Improvement Teams

      



B.   Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Kentucky Distribution Center is managed by Zenith Logistics, Inc.  The facility is a warehouse that  stores perishable and frozen food products for assembly and distribution to retail outlets.  The facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system to provide cooling and freezing capabilities for warehouse areas.  The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in the system is in excess of 10,000 pounds.  The maximum inventory in the system is approximately 45,000 pounds.  An ammonia release from the system poses a risk of offsite public and/or environmental injury or impact.  The system is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  The system is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RMP (40 CFR Part 68) program.

The facility also has a storage and dispensing system for hydrogen (CAS #1333-74-0), a flammable gas stored under pressure.  Hydrogen is brought in via tanker truck and offloaded to the hydrogen storage system located to the west of the warehouse.  The storage units will hold a maximum of 13,400 lbs. of hydrogen.  The hydrogen is piped inside the warehouse for fuel for lifts used inside the warehouse.  There are 3 dispensing/fueling stations inside the warehouse.  A release of hydrogen from the system could pose a risk of offsite injury from fire/explosion, the system is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  The system is also subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RMP program.  The hydrogen storage facilities are operated and maintained by

Air Products, Inc.  The hydrogen dispensing systems are operated and maintained by Plug Power, Inc.



C.   Summary of Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

AMMONIA

The worst-case release scenario at the Kentucky Distribution Center facility for the ammonia refrigeration process involves the release of 12,000 pounds of ammonia over a 10 minute period due to the failure of the control pressure receiver (CPR-1).  This quantity represents the maximum quantity of ammonia in the receiver at any time.  Under worst-case weather conditions, ammonia could travel 1.2 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public. This distance has been calculated based on the method provided in EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR 68) Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration.

The worst-case release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:

?    The worst-case weather conditions which were used for this scenario are not typical and industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of the receiver.  

?    The receiver is located in a low traffic area within the engine room which minimizes the possibility of loss of containment due to vehicular impact (e.g., from forklifts etc.)

?    Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.

?    An ammonia detector is located near the receiver in the engine room.

?    Pressure safety valves limit operating pressure in the receiver.

?    The facility has a preventive maintenance program in place to maintain the on-going integrity of vessels.

?    The facility has a training program designed to ensure that the system is operated by qualified personnel

?    The facility emergency response procedures enable trained personnel to respond quickly to isolate any potential releases.

The alternative release scenario for ammonia at the Kentucky Distribution Center facility involves the release of 1,140 pounds of ammonia over a 60 minute period through a defective pressure safety valve (PSV) on the control pressure receiver (CP

R-1), which lifts to relieve high system pressure but fails to reseat properly.  Under alternative release weather conditions, ammonia could travel 0.1 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.  This distance has been calculated based on the method provided in EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR 68) Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration.

The alternative release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:

?    Industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of the pressure relief devices.

?    The system is operated at considerably lower pressures compared to the PSV's relief pressure setting.

?    Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.

?    The facility has a preventive maintenance program in place to maintain the on-going integrity of the pressure relief devices.

?    The facility has a training program designed to ensure that the system is operated by qualified personnel.

?    The facility emergency response procedures enable trained personnel to respond quickly to isolate potential releases from any leaking equipment.

HYDROGEN

The worst-case release scenario at the Kentucky Distribution Center facility for the hydrogen process involves the release of 11,816 pounds of hydrogen over a 10 minute period due to the failure of the LH2 storage tank.  This quantity represents the quantity of hydrogen in the tank at any time.   This distance has been calculated based on the method provided in EPA's Risk Management Program using RMP Comp to calculate the endpoint distance at which injury may be caused to people.   The calculated endpoint distance was 1,584 feet (.3 miles).

The worst-case release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:

?    The worst-case weather conditions which were used for this scenario are not typical.

?    Industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of the receiver.  

?    The storage vessel is located in a fenced /secured area protected by substantial traffic barrier

s which minimizes the possibility of loss of containment due to vehicular impact.

?    Hydrogen is not corrosive in this service and the vessels are relatively new.

?    The hydrogen system will alarm at a sudden loss of pressure and all compressors and pumps will be shut down.  An Emergency Stop switch is located at the warehouse.

?    Pressure safety valves limit operating pressure in the storage tubes.

?    There is preventive maintenance program in place to maintain the on-going integrity of vessels managed by Air Products, Inc.

?    Air Products has a training program designed to ensure that the hydrogen storage and supply system is operated and maintained by qualified personnel.

The alternative release scenario for hydrogen at the Kentucky Distribution Center facility involves the release of 7,828 pounds of hydrogen over a 119 minute period from a pipe leak at the storage vessels. Under alternative release weather conditions, the endpoint is at .1 miles from the leak.  This distance was calculated using the RMP Comp software provided by the EPA.

The alternative release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:

?    The storage facilities are in a protected area, fenced with substantial traffic barriers around.

?    Hydrogen is not corrosive in this service.

?    The facility has a preventive maintenance program in place to maintain the on-going integrity of the piping.

?    The facility has a training program designed to ensure that the system is operated by qualified personnel.

?    Sudden loss of pressure in the system will cause an alarm and shut the system down.



D.   Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The prevention program, which conforms to PSM/RMP requirements, consists of the following elements:

Employee Participation: This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing all aspects of the program.  Employees are involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted.  The program also ensures that all employees have comple

te access to the program.

Process Safety Information: Written information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the system. The written information includes the hydrogen and ammonia SDS and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration and hydrogen systems.  Information is complete per the PSM/RMP requirements.

Process Hazard Analysis: Formal studies using the What-if and What-If/Checklist  Techniques have been conducted to examine the ammonia refrigeration system and identify potential hazards.  A Process Hazard analysis was performed for both hydrogen storage and dispensing systems using the HAZOP methodology for the storage process and the What-if? Methodology for the dispensing system.  Any recommendations made have been resolved to improve facility safety.  PHAs are reviewed on a five year basis.

Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system.  Procedures are reviewed and updated annually if necessary.

Training: A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained on all aspects of the system and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  Air Products and Plug Power employees are trained by their employers to the PSM/RMP requirements.

Contractors: All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration or hydrogen systems.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.  Air Products and Plug Power employees are also subject to the facility Contractor Safety Program.

Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review is required for all new ammonia refrigeration or hydrogen process equipment and changes to the system.  The review verifies that all safety

programs and procedures are in place, that training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use. They are also performed when there is a change in the process safety information.

Operating Procedures:  Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) are developed for each process covering all the equipment controls and process operations.  The SOPs are developed consistent with PSM/RMP requirements.

Mechanical Integrity:  This program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration and hydrogen systems are built and maintained using recommended and recognized preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.  Zenith maintenance personnel who perform maintenance on the ammonia system are trained regularly and spare parts and maintenance supplies are used which are consistent with good engineering practices and manufacturer's recommendations.  Air Products and Plug Power personnel who perform maintenance on the hydrogen process system are required to train to PSM/RMP and compressed gas industry standards.

Hot Work Permit: This permitting procedure for all hot work ensures that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning; this indicates that all necessary precautions have been taken.

Management of Change: Procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the hydrogen or ammonia refrigeration systems are properly reviewed and that all the necessary information is updated and that safety evaluations, e.g. PHA, have been performed.  This procedure works with the Pre-Startup Safety Review to ensure that any changes implemented are properly reviewed and managed.

Emergency Response:  An Emergency Plan has been developed and employees trained in reporting and responding to alarms and notifications of releases of either hydrogen or ammonia.  The Plan and training includes evacuation procedures for all employees and contractors.  The Plan includes trai

ning and equipment for an Emergency Response Team trained to the HAZWOPER 24 hr. Technician level.  A minimum of two facility employees are trained as Incident Commanders in addition to the Technician Level training.

Incident Investigation: Procedures ensure that any incidents (and near misses) are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team. Any recommendations are resolved to improve the safety of the facility. 

Compliance Audits: There are procedures to conduct regular (3 year) audits of the PSM and RMP processes to ensure that the programs are in place and working properly.  Any recommendations from audits are resolved in a timely fashion.



E.   Five-Year Accident History

There have been no reportable ammonia or hydrogen related incidents at the Kentucky Distribution Center within the last five years which have resulted in either onsite or offsite impacts.



F.   Description of the Emergency Response Program

An emergency response program has been implemented at the Kentucky Distribution Center facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia and hydrogen releases, including evacuation procedures.  The program has been coordinated with the Anchorage/Middletown Volunteer Fire Department.  The facility has cooperated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee to install a Community Alert Siren on facility property which can be used in the event of an ammonia or a hydrogen release which may have off site impact.  Facility emergency plans reflect the siren's presence and use.

The emergency response program consists of the following elements:

         Organization Plan and Responsibilities

         Communications Procedures

         Detailed Action Plans

         First Aid Procedures

         Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures

         Evacuation Plans

         Description of Outside Assistance Available

         Site Re-Entry Procedures

         Training Programs and Drills

        Incident and Release Reporting



G.   Planned Change

s to Improve Safety

The following changes are planned to improve safety conditions and further strengthen the ongoing safety efforts at the Zenith Logistics, Inc. Kentucky Distribution Center facility:  Implementation of a Work Order program which will improve tracking and analysis of ongoing Mechanical Integrity activities.
